name:
Libraries

Curated Libraries
description: Forked and updated from the above list.

name: Curated Libraries
description: Forked and updated from the above list.

name: Bookmark the The Common Lisp Hyperspec.
If you get stuck, find an online community and ask smart questions.
Portacle
description: A portable and multiplatform Common Lisp environment. It ships a slightly customized Emacs with SLIME, SBCL (a popular Common Lisp implementation), Quicklisp and Git. No installation needed, so it's a very quick and easy way to get going.

name: Lispbox
description: An IDE (Emacs + SLIME), Common Lisp implementation (Clozure Common Lisp) and library manager (Quicklisp), pre-packaged as archives for Windows, macOS and Linux. Descendant of "Lisp in a Box" mentioned in Practical Common Lisp.

name: Lispworks Personal Edition
description: A non-Emacs based IDE for LispWorks Lisp, with some restrictions.

name: Allegro Common Lisp
description: Has a free Express Edition IDE, and training videos on YouTube.

name: Articulate Common Lisp
description: A HOWTO for putting together a Lisp environment, and has information on useful libraries and how to structure projects.

name: If you're an experienced Emacs user, you can just install SLIME and a supported Common Lisp implementation. See the SLIME manual for more details.
The Common Lisp Cookbook has more information about installing an implementation using an implementation manager like Roswell, or on Docker.
The Common Lisp Hyperspec (CLHS)
description: The language reference document for Common Lisp. Bookmark it now.

name: Chapter 7
description: Covers the Common Lisp Object System (CLOS).

name: The ANSI Common Lisp Standard Draft
description: The last draft version of the ANSI INCITS 226-1994 (previously ANSI X3.226-1994) standard.

name: The Common Lisp Cookbook
description: A list of useful Lisp recipes. Also contains a list of other online sources of CL information.

name: Common Lisp the Language (2nd Edition) by Guy L. Steele
description: A description of the Common Lisp language from just before it was standardized by ANSI. Don't use it as a reference.

name: Cliki on CLtL2
description: Claims it has more useful descriptions of LOOP and FORMAT than the CLHS does.

name: Stack Overflow on CLtL2
description: Some recommend using CLtL2 for insight and inspiration, but to use the CLHS when programming.

name: A list of differences between CLtL2 and the ANSI Common Lisp specification.
Chapter 28
description: Covers the Common Lisp Object System.

name: Common Lisp: A Gentle Introduction to Symbolic Computation by David S. Touretzky
description: a good introduction for people new to programming. Contains code for really useful utilities like DTRACE and SDRAW.

name: Common Lisp: An interactive approach by Stuart C. Shapiro
description: A textbook that teaches mainly through the use of exercises.

name: Practical Common Lisp by Peter Seibel
description: A great introduction for experienced programmers, and tries to highlight from the very beginning what makes CL different to other languages.

name: Common Lisp Koans
description: Not exactly a book, but a set of koans to help you learn the language.

name: On Lisp by Paul Graham
description: A great book for intermediately experienced Lispers.

name: Let Over Lambda by Doug Hoyte
description: An advanced book on Lisp Macros.

name: Comments on Let Over Lambda
description: Several people recommend that you be comfortable with On Lisp before reading this book, and that the start is slow.

name: The chapter on closures
description: Has several non-trivial examples, and demonstrates the power of this feature.

name: Paradigms of Artificial Intelligence Programming by Peter Norvig
description: Has many interesting applications of Lisp, but is no longer a good reference for AI.

name: Land of Lisp by Conrad Barski, MD
description: A fun introduction to Lisp that uses comics and has you writing games.

name: ANSI Common Lisp by Paul Graham
description: Good as a reference, covers CLOS, and has several example program implementations.

name: Plaintext versions of Chapter 1 and Chapter 2 are available online.
Common Lisp Recipes by Edmund Weitz
description: A great set of Common Lisp patterns.

name: Object-Oriented Programming in Common Lisp by Sonya E. Keene
description: An in-depth description of the CLOS, and shows how to use it with example applications.

name: The Art of the Metaobject Protocol by Gregor Kiczales, Jim des Rivieres, and Daniel G. Bobrow
description: Describes the CLOS Metaobject Protocol (MOP).

name: Chapters 5 and 6 (available online)
description: The specification of a metaobject protocol extension to CLOS.

name: Adam Tornhill on AMOP
description: Recommends reading Practical Common Lisp, then  Object-Oriented Programming in Common Lisp, and then AMOP.

name: The Cliki
description: The Common Lisp Wiki. A great resource for all things CL. Has a great Getting Started page and an extensive list of Lisp books.

name: The #clschool, #lisp, #ccl, #sbcl and other rooms on the Libera.Chat network are great places for learning about Common Lisp. (Freenode should be avoided.)
Lisp Subreddit
description: An active community, and has loads of useful links and reference documents in the sidebar.

name: Common Lisp Subreddit
description: The Subreddit for Common Lisp.

name: Exercism's Common Lisp track
description: An excellent way to learn the language through practice, have your code reviewed, and to discuss solutions with other people.

name: Lisp Discord server
description: Is a Discord for Lisp. Has a channel dedicated to Common Lisp and will happily answer questions.

name: Quicklisp
description: A package management platform for Lisp libraries.

name: Quickdocs
description: Documentation for projects in Quicklisp.

name: State of the Common Lisp Ecosystem, 2015
description: Article about what libraries you should use, and why.

name: Articulate Common Lisp
description: Lists some useful libraries.

name: Allegro Common Lisp (ACL)
description: Commercial, but has a free Express Edition.

name:
Carnegie Mellon University Common Lisp (CMUCL)

CMUCL manual and other useful information
CMUCL manual and other useful information
LispWorks
description: Commercial, but as mentioned previously, has a Personal Edition with minor limitations.

name: Steel Bank Common Lisp (SBCL)
description: My personal favorite.

name: Scieneer Common Lisp (SCL)
description: A commercial Linux and Unix implementation, but has an unrestricted free evaluation and non-commercial use version.
